details.description: Application steps for employers joining the Combined Pension Statement (CPS) service, previously the Combined Pension Forecast (CPF)

parts.title: Overview
parts.body:
The Combined Pension Statement (CPS), previously called the Combined Pension Forecast (CPF), is a voluntary service that lets you combine pension information for your employees in a single statement.

This includes details of their:

  • State Pension
  • workplace or personal pension

How to use the CPS service

  1. Complete the application form and register.

  2. Send sample data for testing.

  3. Get consent from your employees.

  4. Exchange data and issue statements to your employees.

parts.title: Apply and register
parts.body:
Once you’ve decided to join the Combined Pension Statement (CPS) scheme, download and fill in the Pension Service’s application form.

Download ‘Combined Pension Statement application form’ (PDF, 160KB)

Send your completed form to the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP), using the address on the form.

The CPS scheme is voluntary, and you can withdraw at any time.

Registration

DWP will then send you a registration agreement. This includes a schedule telling what you need to do and when, with dates based on the information you gave in your application form.

Contact the Pension Service customer account manager team if you need to change these dates, or have any other queries about the application process.

Pension Service customer account manager

CAM-Team@thepensionservice.gsi.gov.uk
Telephone: 0191 218 2201

parts.title: Perform a data test
parts.body:
Once you confirm that you’re happy with the registration agreement, the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) will ask you to send a small sample of dummy data to run a data test.

They will use this to check that:

  • your file has the right format and structure
  • you’re able to read the return file
  • you can send and receive files successfully

Details of what the data test involves are included in Chapter 4 of the Pension Service’s technical guide.

Download ‘Combined Pension Statement technical guide’ (PDF, 157KB)

parts.title: Get your employees' consent
parts.body:
You need to tell your employees that you’re planning to take part in the Combined Pension Statement (CPS) service, and will be asking the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) for information about their State Pension.

You must must allow your employees the chance to opt out if they do not want you to do this.

You can ask you employees at any time between registering and exchanging live data for the first time.

DWP will provide suggested wording for the consent letter. However, you can adapt the letter to suit your company’s needs, as long as the legal caveats are included.

parts.title: Exchange data and issue statements
parts.body:
Once your data’s been tested and you’ve got your employees’ consent, you’ll need to send their personal details to the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP).

They will estimate each of your employees’ State Pension and send this to you using your chosen data transfer option. The estimates will show the amount of State Pension based on each employee’s National Insurance contribution record so far.

Sending your employees’ statements

DWP will also provide the template you need to send your employees their State Pension information. There are 2 versions of this template, which you’ll get as part of your registration agreement. You can choose which one best fits the design of your existing benefit statements.

You’ll also get leaflets to support each version of the template, which you can send to your employees along with their statements.

The DWP Future Pension Centre can answer your employees’ questions about their State Pension information. Its telephone number is included on each employee’s statement.
